awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Reconfiguration Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational geometry uses graphs, polygons, and arrangements to model physical objects and phenomena. Some of the objects are inherently flexible (e.g., proteins and robotic arms), others are stationary but require adjustments on a regular basis (e.g., communication and transportation networks). The focus of this project is on reconfigurations. The goal is to describe, understand, and control the combinatorial, geometric and topological changes in geometric configurations.
 
This research project will develop new algorithms and data structures for modifying geometric configurations in three areas: (1) Optimization problems for in the configuration space of geometric objects, including graph augmentation, variations of the classical TSP tour problem, and network design for multiple criteria. (2) Reconfiguration through discrete moves, where current challenges include designing efficient data structures to support shortest path computation in the configuration space, approximating the diameter and radius of configuration spaces, and deciding whether reconfiguration is possible. (3) Modeling continuous motion, which includes motion planning algorithms and corresponding dynamic data structures for bar-and-joint frameworks, hinged polygons, and disk arrangements, motivated by applications in protein folding. A unified approach to discrete and continuous reconfiguration problems allows breaking down complex systems into elementary operations, which in turn leads to more efficient computational tools.
 
The collaboration between faculty members and students from two universities ensures a high quality of training and opens new opportunities for all participating students.

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed new algorithmic techniques for the reconfiguration of geometric objects in low-dimensions.

In collaboration with Fulek, the project developed a polynomial-time algorithm for the clustered planarity problem, which was motivated by applications in data visualization, and had been considered elusive for decades. Clustered planarity is a variant of the classical planarity problem: Given a graph with a hierarchical partition of the vertices into clusters, we wish to find a planar realization of the graph and the cluster boundaries. The new algorithm proceeds by a sequence operations that reconfigure the problem into equivalent instances, ultimately reducing the graph to a union of disjoint cycles. Each operation modifies the graph, the clusters, and the underlying space. As such, the reduced problems are no longer planar, and make use of a recent technique developed by Carmesion for the so-called thickenabilty problem in low-dimensional topology.

In collaboration with Dumitrescu, the project has designed approximation algorithms for classical covering and packing problems on anchored rectangles in the plane. These problems are motivated by applications in map labeling and data visualization. We are given a set of points (anchors), each of which is the corner of a rectangle (map label). The goal is to maximize the total area of the labels. Apart from efficient approximations for several variants of the problem, the project has proved upper and lower bounds on the size of the configuration space, the number of local maxima, and optimal bounds on the maximum area covered by anchored squares.

The project also contributed to establishing links between classes of so-called beyond-planar graphs. These are graphs that are quantitatively close to planar graphs, and aid human perception of complex system in data visualization. One notable result is that significant result shows that every two-planar graph is quasiplanar, in other words, if a graph can be represented with up to two crossings per edges, then it also has a drawing without pairwise crossing triples. The proof is constructive, and provides a reconfiguration (rewiring) algorithm for the graph, based on new insights on the intersection patters of edges in these graph classes.

The broader impacts of the project include training one three M.Sci. students and 12 undergraduate researchers.In each year of the grant, a group of 2-4 undergraduate students participated in REU projects, many of them have continued to pursue graduate degrees in computer science or mathematics. During the course of the project, the PI has co-organized research workshops at Dagstul and Shonan on graph embeddings and related problems.
